channel.title: Player state - PI

item.title: Player state - PI
item.dc:creator: @Int_Bauk Int Bauk
item.description:
@Int_Bauk wrote:

Jayden.:

Every server has this…

they have: Misc.println("player logged out..");

not:[quote=“Int Bauk, post:1, topic:515823”]I created this so I know when a player has logged in and logged out from my server, instead of the basic: Misc.println("player logged out..");

Create a new class and call it CreateConnection.java - if not just place these methods in a class (Player.java, for example). You’ll then have to change the parameter to Player.class.getSimpleName (depending on the class you chose).

[code] /** The logger singleton instance, used to log messages to the console. */
private static final Logger logger = Logger.getLogger(CreateConnection.class.getSimpleName());

/**
 * Handles the logout message.
 * @param c
 */
public static void definePlayerState(Client c, int state) {
	switch(state) {
	case 0:
    	logger.log(Level.INFO, Misc.optimizeText(c.playerName) + " has registered into the system.");
		break;
	case 1:
    	logger.log(Level.INFO, Misc.optimizeText(c.playerName) + " has deregistered from the system.");
		break;
	}
}[/code]

initialize method:

destruct method:

Don’t like? don’t use. Doesn’t affect me whether you do or don’t[/quote]

Read full topic

item.title: Player state - PI

@Ashi wrote:


You don't need to make a new method for this.

You don’t need to make a new method for this.

Read full topic

item.title: Player state - PI
item.dc:creator: @relentlesspk relentlesspk
item.description:
@relentlesspk wrote:

I’d rather base them from enums. It looks more appealing to me and more, logical.

    /**
     * The state of the player.
     */
    private enum PlayerState {
        REGISTERED, DEREGISTERED
    }

    /**
     * The logger singleton instance, used to log messages to the console. 
     */
    private static final Logger logger = Logger.getLogger(CreateConnection.class.getSimpleName());

    /**
     * Handles the logout message.
     * @param c
     */
    public static void definePlayerState(Client c, PlayerState state) {
            switch(state) {
            case REGISTERED:
                logger.log(Level.INFO, Misc.optimizeText(c.playerName) + " has registered into the system.");
                    break;
            case DEREGISTERED:
                logger.log(Level.INFO, Misc.optimizeText(c.playerName) + " has deregistered from the system.");
                    break;
            }
    }
Jayden.:

Every server has this…

Why not make it better? It is so messy in PI.

Read full topic

item.title: Player state - PI
item.dc:creator: @Int_Bauk Int Bauk
item.description:
@Int_Bauk wrote:

[quote=“MooningPanda, post:4, topic:515823”]I don’t like this. Deal with it.
I’d rather my server have colorful decorations announcing the logging in and logging off, and not to mention a mariachi band to boot. Hell let’s make Caesar announce a decree that all players who log out must be mentioned on engravings in stone on a wall made in metasquoia![/quote]

you made yourself look like a froob. this doesn’t ‘announce’ whether a player has logged in and/or logged out. it’s what’s printed in the command prompt.

Read full topic

item.title: Player state - PI
item.dc:creator: @Int_Bauk Int Bauk
item.description:
@Int_Bauk wrote:

I created this so I know when a player has logged in and logged out from my server, instead of the basic: Misc.println("player logged out..");

Create a new class and call it CreateConnection.java - if not just place these methods in a class (Player.java, for example). You’ll then have to change the parameter to Player.class.getSimpleName (depending on the class you chose).

[code] /** The logger singleton instance, used to log messages to the console. */
private static final Logger logger = Logger.getLogger(CreateConnection.class.getSimpleName());

/**
 * Handles the logout message.
 * @param c
 */
public static void definePlayerState(Client c, int state) {
	switch(state) {
	case 0:
    	logger.log(Level.INFO, Misc.optimizeText(c.playerName) + " has registered into the system.");
		break;
	case 1:
    	logger.log(Level.INFO, Misc.optimizeText(c.playerName) + " has deregistered from the system.");
		break;
	}
}[/code]

initialize method:

destruct method:

Don’t like? don’t use. Doesn’t affect me whether you do or don’t
